benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/customFields - Modify custom fields to account

covered: Valid PUT requests are extensively covered with multiple success scenarios (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC15) including headers variations, large payloads, and empty-array semantics.

Comprehensive error handling: tests for invalid accountId (TC06), non-existent account (TC07), missing header (TC08), missing body (TC09), malformed JSON (TC10), invalid CustomField schema (TC11), unauthorized (TC12), server down (TC13), and dependency failure (TC14); plus security-related errors (TC20, TC21).
Edge cases: empty array removal (TC15); maximum field lengths (TC16); extra properties ignored (TC17); mixed valid/invalid input (TC18); payload size boundary (TC04, TC26).
Performance and resilience: timeout (TC19), transient network retry (TC22), concurrent requests (TC25), near-limit vs over-limit payload handling (TC26).
Integrations and data flow: audit logs integration (TC27) and external reporting System integration (TC28).
Backward compatibility and regression: duplicate field names test (TC23) and backward compatibility with previous API clients (TC24).
Accessibility: API documentation and error messages accessibility (TC29).
Security checks: SQL injection (TC20) and XSS (TC21).
Optional headers handling: extra/unsupported headers are ignored (TC05).
gaps: Caching behavior and headers testing (ETag, Cache-Control) are not covered.
Rate limiting/throttling scenarios (e.g., HTTP 429) are not covered.
403 Forbidden scenarios (beyond 401) are not explicitly tested.
GET/PATCH/DELETE method coverage is outside this PUT-focused story (not required, but per guidelines they exist in general).
Detailed validation of error response bodies across all error cases is not uniformly asserted (some tests check only status code, not full error payload).
Non-existent account handling status code convention (tests use 400; guidelines mention 4xx; explicit 404 vs 400 not standardized here).
recommendations: Add a dedicated test for 403 Forbidden to cover insufficient permissions scenarios.
Introduce tests validating caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) on PUT responses.
Add rate-limiting tests to ensure proper 429 handling under burst scenarios.
Clarify and test consistent error body structures (especially for 4xx cases) to ensure actionable messages.
Consider an explicit test asserting the 404/400 distinction for non-existent resources and align with API contract.
Optionally extend tests to cover additional partial-update semantics if the API later supports partial updates (to align with PUT guidelines).
